# Template: Letter Before Action - Contentious Probate

<!-- This template provides a framework for pre-action protocol compliance in contentious probate disputes -->

## Usage Instructions

**Purpose:** To comply with pre-action protocol requirements before issuing proceedings  
**When to use:** After preliminary enquiries, before commencing court action  
**Important:** This is a formal pre-action letter. Ensure full compliance with Practice Direction on Pre-Action Conduct and Protocols. Customize all sections. Consider senior review before sending.

---

## Template Letter

**[Your Firm Letterhead]**

**LETTER BEFORE ACTION - URGENT**

**Date:** [Insert date]

**[Recipient Name / Recipient Solicitor]  
[Address Line 1]  
[Address Line 2]  
[City, Postcode]**

**By [First Class Post / Email / Hand Delivery - consider method for urgency and proof]**

Dear [Sir/Madam / Mr./Ms. Surname],

**RE: LETTER BEFORE ACTION  
Estate of [Full Name of Deceased], deceased  
Date of Death: [Insert date]  
[Grant of Probate dated [date] / No grant yet obtained]  
Our Client: [Client name]  
Our Reference: [Matter reference]  
Your Reference: [If known]**

---

### Purpose of This Letter

This is a formal Letter Before Action sent in accordance with the Practice Direction on Pre-Action Conduct and Protocols.

Our client intends to commence proceedings in the [High Court, Chancery Division / County Court at [location]] unless this matter can be resolved without the need for court proceedings.

**You should treat this letter seriously and take immediate legal advice if you have not already done so.**

---

### Parties

**Claimant:** [Client full name], [address]  
[Describe relationship to deceased and capacity - e.g., "daughter of the deceased" / "executor named in the will dated [earlier date]"]

**Defendant(s):** [Full name(s) and capacity - e.g., "as executor(s) under the will dated [date]" / "as beneficiary under the will"]

**Other interested parties:** [List other parties who have an interest in the estate]

---

### Brief Summary of Facts

[Provide clear, chronological summary of key facts:]

1. The deceased died on [date] [having made a will dated [date] / intestate / having made wills dated [dates]].

2. [Summary of will provisions if relevant to claim]

3. [Key events relevant to the dispute, in chronological order]

4. [Facts supporting your client's claim]

5. [Current position - e.g., grant obtained, assets not distributed, etc.]

[Ensure facts are stated clearly and accurately. This is not the place for detailed argument - save that for particulars of claim]

---

### Legal Basis of Claim

Our client's claim is based on [specify legal grounds]:

**[SELECT AND CUSTOMIZE APPROPRIATE SECTION(S)]**

#### Option A: Lack of Testamentary Capacity

The will dated [date] is invalid on the grounds that the deceased lacked testamentary capacity at the time of execution. Specifically:

- [Particularize the lack of capacity - e.g., medical condition, inability to understand nature of will, effects of property, etc.]
- [Reference to medical evidence if available]
- [Reference to circumstances surrounding will execution]

The test for testamentary capacity as set out in *Banks v Goodfellow* (1870) was not satisfied because [brief reasoning].

#### Option B: Undue Influence

The will dated [date] is invalid on the grounds of undue influence. Specifically:

- [Identify the alleged influencer and their relationship]
- [Describe the nature of the influence/coercion]
- [Particularize suspicious circumstances]
- [Explain how the will benefits the influencer]

The will is the product of coercion amounting to undue influence as defined in *Hall v Hall* (1868).

#### Option C: Lack of Knowledge and Approval

The deceased did not know and approve the contents of the will dated [date]. Specifically:

- [Particularize suspicious circumstances - e.g., deceased did not read will, unexpected provisions, involvement of beneficiary in preparation]
- [Reference to evidence showing deceased did not understand contents]

The burden is on you to prove knowledge and approval given the suspicious circumstances.

#### Option D: Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975

Our client claims reasonable financial provision from the estate under the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975 as [specify category of eligible claimant under s.1(1)].

**Limitation:** Our client has [X] months/days remaining until the 6-month deadline from the grant (obtained on [date]).

**Grounds for claim:**
- [State why current provision is unreasonable]
- [Client's financial needs and resources]
- [Deceased's obligations and responsibilities to claimant]
- [Size and nature of estate]
- [Other relevant factors under s.3]

#### Option E: Executor/Administrator Misconduct

[Your client/The executor] has breached their fiduciary duties as executor/administrator. Specifically:

- [Particularize specific breaches - e.g., failure to account, misappropriation, conflict of interest, unreasonable delay]
- [Quantify losses caused by breach]
- [State remedy sought - removal, account, surcharge, etc.]

---

### Summary of Evidence

Our client relies upon the following evidence in support of the claim:

1. **Documentary Evidence:**
   - [List key documents - e.g., medical records, will file, correspondence, estate accounts]

2. **Witness Evidence:**
   - [Identify key witnesses and what they will say]

3. **Expert Evidence:**
   - [If expert evidence obtained or to be obtained - specify type and scope]

[Note: You are not required to disclose all evidence at this stage, but should give a fair summary of the case]

---

### Remedy Sought

Our client seeks the following relief:

**Primary remedy:**
- [E.g., Pronounce against the will dated [date] / Reasonable financial provision of £[amount] / Removal of executor and appointment of substitute / Order for account and surcharge of £[amount]]

**Alternative remedy:**
- [Specify any alternative remedies]

**Additional orders:**
- Interest [specify basis - e.g., pursuant to s.35A Senior Courts Act 1981]
- Costs

---

### Settlement Proposal [If appropriate]

Without prejudice to our client's position, and to avoid the costs and delay of litigation, our client proposes the following settlement:

[Set out clear settlement terms - e.g.:
- Distribution of estate in proportions [specify]
- Payment to client of £[amount]
- Executor to be removed and replaced by [name]
- Each party to bear own costs]

This proposal is made on a without prejudice basis and is open for acceptance until [date - allow reasonable time, usually 14-21 days].

---

### Alternative Dispute Resolution

Our client is willing to consider alternative dispute resolution (ADR) such as mediation or early neutral evaluation before proceedings are issued.

If you are willing to engage in ADR, please confirm this in your response and we can arrange a suitable mediator/neutral.

Please note that the court may impose costs sanctions if a party unreasonably refuses to engage in ADR.

---

### Disclosure

We request that you disclose the following documents within [14 / 21] days:

1. [List essential documents needed - e.g., will file, medical records, estate accounts, correspondence]

2. [Any documents you are entitled to pre-action disclosure of]

We will provide appropriate undertakings as to use and confidentiality if required.

---

### Response Required

Please provide a full response to this letter within **[14 / 21 / 28] days** of the date of this letter, by **[insert specific date]**.

Your response should:

1. State whether you admit or deny the claim
2. If denied, provide detailed reasons for the denial
3. Identify what documents you will disclose
4. State your position on settlement and ADR
5. Confirm whether you are taking legal advice and provide details of your solicitors

---

### Limitation and Urgency [If applicable]

[For Inheritance Act claims:]
**URGENT:** We must highlight that our client's claim under the Inheritance Act 1975 is subject to a strict 6-month limitation period from the date of the grant. The grant was obtained on [date] and therefore the deadline for issuing proceedings is **[date]**.

Given the limited time available, it is essential that you respond promptly. If settlement cannot be reached, we will be compelled to issue proceedings to protect our client's position.

[For other claims where there is urgency:]
**URGENT:** [Explain any urgency - risk of dissipation of assets, health issues, etc.]

---

### Consequences of Failure to Respond

If you do not respond within the time specified, or if your response is inadequate, our client will:

1. Issue proceedings without further notice to you
2. Draw the court's attention to your failure to engage with this pre-action process
3. Seek an order for costs on an indemnity basis
4. [If appropriate: Seek interim relief such as an injunction to preserve estate assets]

---

### Costs Warning

You should be aware that:

1. If our client is successful, [they will seek their costs from the estate / you may be personally liable for costs depending on your conduct]

2. The costs of litigation in contentious probate cases can be substantial

3. Early settlement will save significant costs for all parties

4. The court has power to make adverse costs orders against parties who unreasonably refuse settlement or ADR

---

### Preservation of Assets [If appropriate]

**IMPORTANT:** You must not distribute any assets of the estate pending resolution of this matter. If you do so, you may be personally liable to our client and we will seek an immediate injunction and your removal as executor.

We put you on notice that any distribution made after receipt of this letter may be set aside and you may be surcharged personally.

---

### Next Steps

We await your substantive response by [deadline date].

If this matter can be resolved by agreement, we are instructed to negotiate in good faith. If proceedings become necessary, our client will pursue the claim vigorously.

Please ensure your solicitors (if instructed) contact us as soon as possible.

---

Yours [sincerely / faithfully],

---

**[Fee Earner Name]**  
**[Position]**  
**[Your Firm Name]**  
**[Email]**  
**[Telephone]**  
**[Reference]**

---

## Enclosures [If appropriate]

- [ ] Copy of [earlier will / medical report / other key document]
- [ ] Schedule of [assets / proposed distribution / etc.]

---

## Drafting Checklist

Before sending, ensure:

- [ ] All placeholder text replaced with case-specific information
- [ ] Facts accurately and clearly stated
- [ ] Legal basis clearly identified with correct authorities
- [ ] Limitation position checked and stated if applicable
- [ ] Settlement proposal is realistic and clearly expressed
- [ ] Response deadline is reasonable and specific date given
- [ ] All relevant evidence summarized
- [ ] Remedy sought is clearly stated
- [ ] Appropriate level of urgency conveyed
- [ ] Tone is firm but professional
- [ ] Supervisor/senior fee earner review completed
- [ ] Client approval obtained (if required)
- [ ] Proof of posting/service will be obtained
- [ ] Copy saved to matter file with appropriate filename
- [ ] Deadline diarized for response
